Answer: Reasonably likely.Medical, bioengineering, etc., is starting to do some very significant work and you have a lot of time to take advantage of this.However, you are most likely to die pre-maturally from Heart Disease, Cancer, Accidents, Guns, or Suicide, so if you want to see 2100+, avoid all of these, they do kill a lot of people.A few years ago I read that the “first person to live to 150 was alive today”.

name: Igor Markov
question: https://www.quora.com/I-was-born-in-the-year-2005-how-likely-is-it-that-I-will-see-the-year-2100-with-the-help-of-upcoming-technologies

Answer: It is highly unlikely I will be alive in 2100 as I would be 126 years old at that point.That being said it is difficult to ascertain exactly where science will bring us in the next 80 years. There are scientists studying the process of aging and cell death and deterioration which may eventually develop treatments which extend human life expectancy well beyond what is possible at the moment.There are also a number of people exploring the possibility of uploading a person’s consciousness to a computerized matrix which theoretically would allow people to exist in perpetuity disembodied.These formIt is highly unlikely I will be alive in 2100 as I would be 126 years old at that point.That being said it is difficult to ascertain exactly where science will bring us in the next 80 years. There are scientists studying the process of aging and cell death and deterioration which may eventually develop treatments which extend human life expectancy well beyond what is possible at the moment.There are also a number of people exploring the possibility of uploading a person’s consciousness to a computerized matrix which theoretically would allow people to exist in perpetuity disembodied.These forms of exploration of human existence may well produce some tangible methods in which by the time I come into my old age (should I make it that far) which might allow me to exist much longer than is possible now, if not forever.The question as to whether or not I might choose to take such measures remains unknown to me at this moment. I am as bothered and baffled by the knowledge of my own finite existence as any one else and so am certainly curious about the prospect of “living” forever, or for a very long time.I do wonder though what that existence would be like, what it might feel like to know I will live to be 200 or my consciousness will never die. I wonder how I might live my life knowing it can be extended beyond what is possible at this moment. I wonder if it would be even remotely enjoyable, or meaningful, or joyful to live without a body at all. I wonder how a disembodied consciousness would interact with the embodied world or the artificial world of other disembodied persons. I wonder what my human rights as a disembodied person might be and what my consciousness might be used for. Would anyone even care that I continued to exist within a network of electronically mitigated nodes? I am certainly concerned about the prospect of taking efforts to extend my life by some length only to discover that extension is a miserable existence. Will there be a way to pull the proverbial plug and will that be up to me?
name: Michael Forrest Jones
